chapter.title: Composition of Functions and Inverses of Functions

li.p: Define composite functions and combinations of functions and apply and interpret these in appropriate situations.
Evaluate, apply, and interpret function notation, including the notation for inverse functions and composition of functions.
Demonstrate the inverse relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function (with the same base).

conclusion.title: Gist of Composition and Inverses
conclusion.p: The composition of functions is really about making one function the input for another. Here is a medical example of the composition of two functions. Let f(t) be a function that relates the amount of drug, D in , in a patient's bloodstream as a function of time, t in hours. At time goes on, the amount of drug in the paritent's body decreases as the body eliminates it.

On the other hand, the drug is meant to help slow the heart rate of a patient, so as the drug leaves the patient's bloodstream, the heart rate increases. Therefore, the heart rate H, in beats per minute, is a function of D, the amount of drug in the body. We can write H = g(D) where g is a function relating the Heart rate to the amount of drug in the body.
Therefore we have two functions: the heart rate is a function of the amount of drug in the bloodstream and the amount of drug is a function of time. Utimately, the heart rate is a function of time.

Using function notation the composition of these two functions looks like this:H=g(D)\text{ and }D=f(t)\text{ so that }H=g(f(t))\text{.} If each function had a formula then we would literally put one formula into the other.
